intro: Chirita orthandra, commonly known as the golden groundsel, is a herbaceous perennial native to parts of Africa and the Middle East. It belongs to the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads and opposite leaves. The plant typically grows to a height of 10–30 cm, featuring hairy stems and lance-shaped leaves with serrated edges. Its bright yellow flowers bloom in late spring to early summer, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies. Chirita orthandra is often cultivated in gardens for its ornamental value and ability to thrive in well-drained soils.
